"the 1860 election happened and there was no willingness to accept the results, and that of course leads to the civil war. i don't think that's going to happen here, but the idea that a candidate might not accept the results, and that would be part of his big sell to the public, that's not something we've seen before." trump's nomination alone had been groundbreaking. the bombastic real-estate mogul gained renown in the world of reality tv, not politics or government -- the first major-party candidate since world war ii to lack any experience in government or military command, and one often at odds with the establishment of the party he led. clinton's nomination was groundbreaking as well: the former secretary of state was the first woman nominated for president by a major party in the 240-year history of the republic. sixteen months ago, they launched their candidacies within days and a mile of one another, at trump tower and on roosevelt island. here's a look at what happened in their final showdown tuesday, and why. women roared maybe this shouldn't be a surprise: the campaign featuring the first female nominee -- and one running against a male opponent accused of sexual harassment -- was heading toward an historic gender gap. men backed trump by nine points; women backed clinton by 14, a wider margin than they had given barack obama four years ago. the exit polls indicated that the gender gap, the difference in support for a candidate between male and female voters, likely would surpass the record of 11 percentage points in the 1996 presidential campaign that re-elected bill clinton. close to six in 10 women said his treatment of women bothered them "a lot;" just over four in 10 men felt that way. a majority of college-educated women voted for the democratic candidate for the first time since at least 1952, when exit polls allowed demographics characteristics to be analyzed. but the key divisions tuesday weren't only about gender. they also were about education. white women who weren't college graduates? they backed trump by double digits. blue-collar whites turned red there was a time when white men without a college education -- men who worked with their hands, including those in unions -- were a backbone of the democratic coalition fdr forged. but this year, that group gave trump his most avid support, embracing his message that unwise trade deals and competition for jobs from illegal immigrants had cost them their place in the middle class. they backed him by close to 3-1. while clinton was endorsed by the leadership of most labor unions, voters from union households backed her only narrowly. latinos turned out almost two-thirds of latinos were supporting clinton -- or, perhaps, opposing trump for his harsh rhetoric about deporting illegal immigrants and a huge wall along the southern border
Title: Next leader will inherit division

Text: democrats needed to gain 30 seats to seize control of the house. that's an unlikely outcome, congress watchers agree. "that would mean an unbelievable night," said barry burden, a professor of political science at the university of wisconsin-madison and director of its elections research center. at midnight, republicans had won 207 seats to 148 for democrats. it takes 218 to claim the majority. upsetting the republicans would have required a huge win on hillary clinton's part, on the order of a double-digit win for her to lift the rest of the party's candidates, burden said.  late tuesday, trump led clinton in several battleground states, all but eliminating the chance that she could sweep other democrats into office with her. the democrats' other dilemma: they received more votes overall nationally in 2014, but still lost seats -- largely because they ran up the score in safe districts. republicans will likely lose seats after tuesday's voting, burden said, in the range of 10 to 20. if they lose fewer than 10, that will indicate a good night for the gop, he said. if they lose more -- as many as 15 to 20, democrats should take heart. sarah binder, a senior fellow at the brookings institution and a political science professor at george washington university, agreed that a loss of fewer than 10 seats would be a net positive for republicans. david wasserman differed just a bit, putting his marker at 13 republican losses. if the democrats win more than 13, they should be pleased. if they win fewer, republicans can breathe easier, according to wasserman, house editor for the cook political report. in florida, republicans held on to two competitive seats, but lost one. in an open seat in eastern florida, including part of palm beach county, brian mast defeated democrat randy perkins after the democratic incumbent patrick murphy opted to run for the senate. murphy lost to republican sen. marco rubio. in another closely watched race, the incumbent republican carlos curbelo held off democrat joe garcia in south florida. but in the orlando area, democrat stephanie murphy beat 12-term incumbent john mica, a fixture in florida politics. the district boundaries were redrawn last year and held fewer republicans. also in florida's st. petersburg area, former governor charlie crist, a one-time republican and then independent who ran as a democrat in tuesday's election, helped the democrats pick up one seat in the house. crist beat republican incumbent david jolly. what's likely to be apparent on wednesday, burden said, is a smaller, more conservative majority as the gop's losses will probably come in suburban districts, home to more moderate republicans. the slimmer, more conservative majority will make it more difficult to re-elect house speaker paul ryan of wisconsin and to pass legislation, burden said. ryan, as expected, won his race. republicans, based on their campaign ads, have focused on local issues, binder said in an email. while democrats have attempted to "nationalize" races by linking republicans to donald trump. one of the more competitive races, burden said, simmers in wisconsin where republican rep. reid ribble, from the green bay area and a member of the 'never trump' club, is not seeking reelection. rep. barbara comstock, r-va., won an expensive race against her democratic challenger luann bennett in their suburban washington district. that race saw the two candidates saturate the airwaves with advertisements in the closing weeks of the race. comstock won the endorsement of the washington post. in new york, republican incumbent john katko, a freshman, held off a challenge from democrat colleen deacon in another closely watched race in the central part of the state. binder will also be watching the races of two republican incumbents on opposite coasts: scott garrett in new jersey and darrell issa in california
Title: Republicans keep hold on the House; Caucus slightly smaller but more conservative

Text: democrats picked up a seat in illinois and were ahead in pennsylvania and nevada, where they were fighting to hold the seat held for 30 years by sen. harry reid. democrats needed a net gain of five seats to win a majority, or four seats to split the senate 50-50. in the event of an evenly divided senate, the party that wins the white house would effectively win the senate majority since the vice president acts as the tie-breaking vote. democratic rep. tammy duckworth ousted republican sen. mark kirk in illinois. duckworth, who was first elected to the house in 2012, lost both of her legs in combat in iraq; kirk suffered a stroke during his only term in the senate. democrats also were leading in pennsylvania, with former state environmental chief katie mcginty ahead of republican sen. pat toomey. in nevada, democratic former attorney general catherine cortez masto was leading republican rep. joe heck in early returns as they competed for the open seat of retiring senate minority leader  reid. in indiana, republican rep. todd young beat two-term former senator evan bayh for an open seat created by the retirement of gop sen. dan coats. bayh was a late entrant to the race and had an early lead in polls. and in north carolina, gop sen. richard burr, chairman of the senate intelligence committee, defeated democratic former state representative deborah ross. but the most unexpected victory for republicans was in wisconsin, where gop sen. ron johnson won a rematch against democratic former sen. russ feingold, who had led johnson by double digits in polls just a few weeks ago. the party that controls the senate will help determine whether the new president can push his or her agenda through congress for the next two years. if the early trend holds, the republicans would maintain control, which would give them power over both chambers of congress for another two years. if republican presidential nominee donald trump wins, the gop will hold the executive and legislative branches. democrats believed they could wrench the majority away from republicans because the gop had so many more seats to defend
Title: Dems' hopes fade for Senate; Duckworth a victor in Illinois, but GOP hanging on to key seats

Text: the early results surprised pollsters and rattled investors. dow futures plunged 600 points, or 3.3%, as the markets worried about the uncertainty of a trump administration. with trump holding narrow leads in states like georgia and north carolina, the real estate mogul widened his previous narrow path to victory. the razor-thin vote followed an equally divisive 2016 presidential campaign to decide whether the united states will continue or reject the policies of president obama. turnout was up. in the 1,143 counties with 100% precincts reporting as of 10:45p.m.et, 5.6% more voters cast votes than in 2012. the race pitted two largely unpopular candidates with singular qualities: former secretary of state clinton, who would be the first female president after 228 years of men, against reality television star trump, whose vast wealth, lack of government experience and brash style could redefine the word "presidential." even before the vote-casting turned to vote-counting, a sense of history hung over the day. many women wore pantsuits to the polls, an homage to clinton's conservative sartorial style. hundreds of women made a pilgrimage to a rochester, n.y. cemetery, affixing their "i voted" stickers to the headstone of susan b. anthony, the suffragist leader whose work paved the way for women to earn the right to vote. nearly a century later, gender issues were never far from the forefront of clinton's barrier-breaking campaign -- or from trump's. his insult-laden speeches and tweets -- which his supporters defended as a refreshing break from political correctness -- were recounted in attack ads that flooded battleground states in the final weeks. indeed, it was an election decided as much on character as on issues. nearly two-thirds of voters who spoke to exit pollsters said they were bothered by clinton's use of a private email server. even more said they were bothered by trump's treatment of women -- with more than half saying that his conduct bothered them "a lot." more than one-tenth of voters said they made up their minds on how to vote in the last few days of the campaign, as the fbi revealed its on-again, off-again investigations into clinton's emails. justin byerly of asheville, n.c., said his decision was difficult. "until 11 days ago, i was for hillary," he said. "then the emails happened." exit polls revealed an electorate more educated, more diverse -- and also angrier -- than recent presidential elections. clinton was counting on a big turnout from hispanic and african-american voters, while trump's support was fueled by a frustration about the direction of the country after eight years of obama. clinton and trump both cast their own ballots in solid-blue new york state tuesday morning. clinton and husband bill arrived to cheers at her polling place in chappaqua, n.y. trump's reception at his manhattan polling place was more mixed. he finished voting and then appeared to peek over at wife melania's ballot. asked who he voted for, he nodded and joked, "tough decision." voters faced long lines at many polling places but no major impediments, even as an estimated 90 million americans filed through schools, churches, public libraries, civic centers and grocery stores to cast ballots. fears of voting problems pushed voting rights advocates, conservative watchdogs and even international observers to monitor voting. still, trump's frequent complaints that the process would be "rigged" seemed to have an effect on voter confidence. one in six voters counted in exit polls said they were unsure whether their vote would be counted correctly -- up from one in 10 in 2008. republicans were more skeptical than democrats. contributing: heidi m
Title: Trump scores crucial victories in Florida, Ohio

Text: but elation led to worry by evening, as gop presidential nominee donald trump challenged  democratic nominee hillary clinton in key swing states. when polls opened, the possibility of ending the night with two words -- madam president -- proved electric, and emotions ran the gamut from euphoria to tears. as clinton supporters hit the polls, some women (and men) voters wore white, a nod to the suffrage movement that afforded women the right to vote in 1920. in rochester, n.y., thousands of people, a large majority of them women and girls, queued up to visit the grave of women's rights crusader susan b. anthony, who famously cast a ballot in 1872 knowing it was illegal, and was subsequently arrested. born before she had the right to cast a ballot, "i'd like to vote twice but that's not possible," said 100-year old florence thaler, a resident of pequannock township, n.j. at poll stations, women arrived with their mothers, daughters and sisters. many wore pantsuits as a nod to clinton's signature look. "just high fived a #pantsuit wearing wearing stranger. this is a weird day," tweeted lucy arnold, whose bio identifies her as a teacher and writer. in columbia, s.c., consultant elizabeth wilson set a soundtrack to her day, playing beyoncí©'s run the world (girls) and fleetwood mac's don't stop on her instagram story-documented morning walk to her polling station. "i was feeling excited, ecstatic, happy, lucky to be part of this historic moment," said wilson. "the country as been ready, for a few decades, for a woman president." but by tuesday night, twitter became a current of worry due to the razor-thin voting margins. "i'm so anxious and stressed. my stomach is in knots," wrote user @michellef0918. "this election and trump's language has brought up so many traumas for women and this is half the nation telling us, "oh well," tweeted @alysemigran. in iowa, ruline steininger, 103, began her night watching cnn's early return, offering a stern "good!" after each state was  called for clinton. steininger cast her first vote for franklin d. roosevelt in 1940. starting with her annual christmas letter last year, she willed herself to live, writing to her friends and family she "decided to stay alive to vote for hillary." "i thought it was great that a black man got elected for president," she said tuesday. "i didn't think that would happen in my lifetime, but it did. now, it is high time for a woman, and this time we have a woman who is really capable of being president of the united states." but when the network reported that trump was leading  -- at least temporarily -- in florida, she set  her tea down with emphasis. "don't tell me that," she all but yelled at the tv. at dawn in rochester, the mood was jubilant and reflective. supporters continued the tradition of decorating suffragette susan b. anthony's headstone at mount hope cemetery with their "i voted" stickers. "i'm voting for the first woman president. as a woman i can vote because of the sacrifices she made," said gillian paris of brighton, n.y., who affixed her sticker to anthony's marker shortly after sunrise. "i never cried when i filled out my ballot before. but i realized my daughters -- and i have three of them -- have the right to vote for a woman. it made me cry," said jodi atkin of irondequoit, n.y., who trekked to the grave site with daughter jessie. both were clad in white. first-time voter kayci reynolds, 19, in phoenix, threw up her arms as she left a downtown phoenix polling site and yelled, "i voted for hillary clinton!" in greenville, s.c.,  inez tenenbaum, south carolina's former state superintendent of education said america was long overdue to have a woman at the helm. "other women, such as margaret thatcher, angela merkel, indira gandhi, golda meir have led countries for decades," said tenenbaum, an attorney who was nominated by president barack obama in 2009 to chair the united states consumer product safety commission. dusty deming, a greenville, s.c., marketing and public relations professional, said she hoped a clinton win would lead to women's leadership in business and government to be be taken more seriously. "maybe it will inspire women to take on the mantle of leadership and believe that it is theirs and not be so deferential to tradition," she said
Title: For millions of women, this Election Day is like no other; Nerves were tight, but the joy of voting for a woman was strong

Text: with trump leading the  popular vote after the polls in many states had closed, trump nation waited to see if their candidate could overcome hillary clinton's edge in pre-election polls. "i'm an emotional wreck," rachel quade, 50, who had been up poll-watching since 5 a.m., texted from a trump-pence party in downtown indianapolis. "i'm going to cry either way!" at home in vermillion s.d., lora hubbel, 58, was another bundle of nerves. "i'm trying to stay busy and only look at the results once in a while," she said. she busied herself online, pursuing real estate continuing-education credits. hubbel, one of many white christian evangelicals who voted for the very non-evangelical trump, said she had faith he'd win. with him in the white house, "everyone's going to get a little more testosterone!" she said. "this means more freedom, more initiative." both women were among scores of trump voters around the nation interviewed this summer by the usa network. others were more confident, based on trump's solid showing tuesday in battleground states. nam yong horn, 62, said she wasn't even considering the possibility of a trump loss: "oh my god, america is going to be saved!" the 62-year-old korean immigrant, who lives in southern california, spent last weekend working for trump in las vegas. "we'll have a real human being in the white house who understands the people," she predicted. eugene dunn, a long island limo driver who took his son out of school to attend trump's announcement 17 months ago at trump tower, said he had "the champagne on ice" as he awaited the verdict. "no one i know says they're voting for hillary clinton," he said. "and you look at the yard signs, it was 20-to-1." losing was unthinkable -- except, he said, that if trump lost he'd have to consider "an exit strategy" such as "moving to the islands, maybe tending bar at a tiki bar." at the other end of the hope spectrum was barry fixler, a small-town jeweler who opened his own local trump headquarters last year when the campaign didn't do so fast enough. "donald trump said this election is rigged, and i fully agree with him," said fixler, whose shop is in bardonia, n.y., north of new york city. "i cannot see president obama turning over the government. i'm not being pessimistic, i'm being realistic." as the votes were counted, the trump optimists and the trump pessimists shared one thing: relief that the campaign was over. jeff lau, 58, who owns a brew pub in york, pa., called it "the ugliest i've ever seen." he was hardly sanguine about what came next, regardless of whether his man won or lost, or whether the gop maintained control of the house and senate. "donald is a little vindictive, and instead of negotiating he'll probably try to dictate to republicans in congress, who didn't really support him," lau said. "they'll push back, and then we'll have gridlock." trump supporters were torn between pondering the benefits of his election and the costs of his defeat. erwin jackson, a tallahassee, fla., landlord and real estate manager, said a clinton presidency would mean higher taxes and more regulation and could drive him into retirement: "why work harder? it's just more stress. i'm 66. all four of my brothers have retired. my sons say, 'dad, you've worked all these years.'" besides such personal concerns, many in trump nation feared for what a defeat would mean for the political process. the aforementioned quade, a 50-year-old real estate agent who lives in suburban indianapolis, said a trump loss would "mean we're going to a one-party system. if we can't win against such a weak candidate, we have no chance of ever winning again." trump himself had encouraged such an attitude the previous day, when he said there was no substitute for victory and no consolation in defeat. if he didn't win, he said at a rally in north carolina, "we've all wasted our time." he also told a crowd in sarasota, fla.: "they say we'll get a tremendous amount of credit, win or lose. i said, 'no, no, no, no.' i don't want any credit if we lose." he sounded an apocalyptic note. "we will never have another opportunity." many of his followers agreed. "this is not the country i grew up in," said pat acciavatti, 77, of st. clair township, mich., a retired excavating company owner. he spoke of the 1940s and '50s, when america made half the world's steel in the wake of world war ii. now, he said, "we're going in the wrong direction. donald trump has a chance to change that. he's the only hope the country has
Title: In Trump Nation, hope and anxiety; Anger is replaced by emotion: 'I'm going to cry either way'

Text: while the winner was still undetermined as this edition went to press, one thing remained clear: whoever comes out on top, it is imperative for the nation and its political leaders to honor the eventual outcome and address the issues of national importance. if trump eventually wins, he deserves to be accorded the respect of other presidents-elect. should clinton prevail, trump and his backers will gain little by raising unreasonable doubts about "rigged" results. as tuesday's nail-biting contests in a number of nations showed, america  is a deeply polarized nation. and trump's support, despite his huge flaws, reflects many voters' frustration with government's ability to improve their lives. but there is little indication that americans have much sympathy for sore losers. the united states has pressing needs that won't be addressed by pouting and infantile partisanship. while washington can't snap its fingers and bring back millions of low-skill factory jobs, it can and must refrain from making matters worse. in recent years, with the two parties at war with each other, the national debt has soared as the result of off-budget spending on retirement and health care. at the same time, government has vastly underspent on infrastructure and left key issues such as tax simplification and immigration reform languishing. if lawmakers and the next president were to actually address some of these issues, they could give a boost to the economy and lessen some of the anger directed their way. the early signs of this happening are, to be sure, not good. republicans retained their house majority on tuesday, and their caucus is increasingly under the control of hard-liners who favor government shutdowns and threats  to default on the national debt as ploys to gain leverage. democrats, meanwhile, have fallen more under the wing of populists such as sens. bernie sanders and elizabeth warren who push fanciful social spending proposals. whoever emerges as president needs to find ways to bridge these gaps, and the two parties will have to stop behaving like spoiled children and start acting on the people's behalf. early talk of impeaching the winning candidate will not do anything, either. house republicans tried impeachment in 1998, pursuing charges against then-president bill clinton despite widespread opposition from voters. the result: the gop vastly underperformed in that november's midterm elections, and clinton went on to enjoy high ratings in his final two years in the oval office. the american people are not  as petty as their politicians. every day they do innovative things and solve myriad problems while interacting across racial, ethnic, gender and generational lines. they solve their own problems without looking to washington for help
Title: Honor the outcome, and address the issues

Text: their candidate for president will have lost the election, and many of them will be convinced the outcome was unfair or, given their intense dislike for the winner, simply unacceptable. the winner should of course make clear that he or she is president of all americans, not just his or her supporters, but it will be up to the loser to unite us. ... this is not about donald trump or hillary clinton; this is about the future of american constitutional democracy, and the obligation to protect it rests on both candidates, win or lose." lasvegasreviewjournal, editorial: "these are turbulent times. more and more americans express frustration and disillusionment today with the political institutions that govern the nation. they clamor for an alternative to the incestuous and pernicious atmosphere dominating the capital. ... the discontent isn't confined by ideology or political philosophy. as donald trump confounded the pundit class in ignoring convention and protocol on his way to securing the republican presidential nomination, a longtime socialist generated throngs of enthusiastic supporters on the left and almost derailed the democratic coronation of hillary clinton. ... trump represents neither the danger his critics claim nor the magic elixir many of his supporters crave. but he promises to be a source of disruption and discomfort to the privileged, back-scratching political elites ... for whom the nation's strength and solvency have become subservient to power's pursuit and preservation. donald trump for president." thenewyorker, editorial: "the election of hillary clinton is an event that we (would) welcome for its immense historical importance, and greet with indescribable relief. ... trump really does represent something singular. the prospect of such a president -- erratic, empty, cruel, intolerant and corrupt -- represents a form of national emergency. ... at a time of alarming and paralyzing partisanship, this is an issue that reasonable voices in both parties can agree upon. at last count, more than a 160 republican leaders had declared their refusal to support trump. fifty national-security officials who served in republican administrations have done the same
Title: This is about the future of democracy

Text: indiana lt. gov. eric holcomb, a republican, won the governor's seat vacated by vice presidential candidate mike pence over democratic rival john gregg, the state house speaker. west virginians elected a democrat for their governor, millionaire coal executive jim justice, even though they overwhelmingly sided with donald trump for president. former software entrepreneur doug burgum kept north dakota's governor's seat with republicans, while u.s. rep. john carney, a democrat, won delaware's governor's seat. in utah, republican gov. gary herbert beat out democratic rival mike weinholtz to win re-election, making him one of the longest-standing governors in the u.s. he's held his post for more than 11 years. entering tuesday, democrats were defending eight gubernatorial seats, while the republicans were trying to hold four. at least six of those races were seen as competitive or tossups. as in other down-ballot races, the presidential contest -- and trump's candidacy in particular -- could impact several of those matchups. trump's widespread support among hard-line gop voters appeared to help holcomb in indiana and justice in west virginia and perhaps eric greitens in missouri, where the race was too close to be called. and vermont, one of the most liberal states in the union, could see itself with a republican in the governor's mansion. why are governor's races important? for starters, governors will be the ones signing off on -- or rejecting -- any new redrawing of legislative districts, said larry sabato, director of the university of virginia's center for politics. also, despite the drama of the presidential elections, voters tend to care more about who's leading their state government than who's occupying the white house, he said. "washington is often only relevant in war and peace," sabato said. "at the state level, your everyday life is affected." two of the closer contests for governor include: north carolina incumbent pat mccrory had been under intense national scrutiny this year for overseeing controversial laws, including hb2, nicknamed the "bathroom bill," which prohibited transgender residents from using public bathrooms of the gender they identify with, and a voting law that was struck down by the courts. protests and boycotts ensued in the wake of hb2, including the ncaa's announcement that it was relocating its championship games. democratic attorney general roy cooper led in recent polls and could end up benefiting from the democrats' get-out-the-vote efforts. his republican rivals had criticized his handling of state crime labs and the state bureau of investigation. vermont one of more surprising races of the season, vermont might choose to go with a republican governor even though it's an overwhelmingly democratic and liberal state. republican lt. gov. phil scott is popular and seen as socially liberal, which could wind up helping his chances in the freedom and unity state. former state transportation secretary sue minter, a democrat, is challenging scott
Title: Heads of states: Wins divvy up; Gubernatorial races haven't had much buzz -- yet resonate widely

Text: history for the past five decades has seen an increasingly powerful and more powerful president and executive branch. from getting us into wars, to using the vast regulatory network of the federal government to intervene and control american lives, the executive branch's power far exceeds that which would be acceptable to our founding fathers. this presidential election was between two unpopular candidates. so, no matter who wins, the new president will start with the worst favorable ratings in  presidential history. all new presidents start with one of their highest approval ratings. but as the presidents act in a managerial way, by running the government, their acts cause disagreement and thus their approval wanes. this is the result of making hard decisions and compromises. on jan. 20, the 45th president will be loathed by half the american public, which means the power will go back to america's elected representatives and senators. the "all powerful" american president ruling-like-a-king threat that we have already been experiencing will stop and power will go back to the people, where the founding fathers wanted it. kevin kelly ironia, n.j. facebook the idea that our country will always have the opportunity to recover and regroup is one that can only be held by someone who is ignorant of history and reality. there are indeed points of no returns. steve minton this country has survived a war for its independence, a civil war that tore our country apart, wars to prevent tyranny in other countries, numerous financial crises and political scandals that tested our ethical mettle. and amazingly this country is still standing. this country isn't perfect, but we (the people) try to right the wrongs to make it better. eric fuller twitter our followers shared their experiences voting on election day. i voted early in wisconsin where more absentee ballots were returned than in the last two presidential elections. @jeffostach with the potential of having our first female president and our first native-american congressman from north dakota, it felt empowering! @travradiofm my mom voted for the first time. she said it's an important election for women and she wanted to play a part in making history! @brendaoffduty here in oregon, i voted by mail early, safely and at my convenience. why are we not all doing this? @thebarrelmaker i voted for hillary clinton! it's a small town, so it took me five minutes. @mlsink i'm worried about voter corruption and fraud during this election. @kaylace4 i arrived at the polling site at 6 a.m., and there wasn't a long line. got in, and voted with no problems
Title: We were tested this year, now let's move forward

Text: bakers across the nation have created hillary clinton and donald trump-themed confections to amp up business and take part in the political banter. here are three "cookie elections" across the nation: busken bakery  in cincinnati every election year since 1984, busken bakery has baked  up  batches of candidate cookies and  sold them as something of a straw poll. as of tuesday morning, trump  had the lead with 16,756 "votes" and clinton followed with 15,200. naturally, tuesday was the last day to cast a vote. dan busken, president of busken bakery, also introduced a new option this year for "undecided and disenchanted voters": the cookie party cookie,  topped with a yellow smiley face. last we checked, the cookie party had 12,694 votes. uncle mike's bake shoppe in green bay, wis. uncle mike's bake shoppe has been selling cookies decorated with  caricatures of each presidential candidate since the republican and democratic national conventions were held in july. in the spirit of the election year, it has kept track of every cookie sold. the uncle mike's polls didn't  officially close until both shops  did at 6 p.m. tuesday, but the  latest cookie tally  had trump with 1,623 cookies and clinton with 1,426, said owner mike vande walle. that gives trump the edge with 53%  to clinton's 47%. uncle mike's planned  to post the final results of the cookie poll on its facebook page  tuesday night. oakmont bakery, inc. in oakmont, pa. oakmont bakery  also has joined the "confection election." as of monday night, trump was in the lead with nearly 4,000 "votes." the bakery is also featuring other election-related sweets, including cookie cakes. jeremy fugleberg of the cincinnati enquirer and kendra meinert of green bay (wis
Title: A potpourri of politics; From 'cookie' contests to an offer to flee the country, Americans weighed many issues as they headed to the polls on Election Day

Text: 70 chg: -$8.04 % chg: -22.5% day's high/low: $27.75/$17.20 the rental car company reported weak quarterly earnings and outlook. its shares gapped down premarket and went down further, losing more than half of their value before they spiked up midday. tesla price: $194.94 chg: $1.73 %chg: 0.9% day's high/low: $197.49/$191.26 the electric-car maker is buying grohmann engineering to help automate and accelerate production while it's seeking approval for solarcity merger. stock price nearly made up november's loss. valeant pharmaceuticals price: $14.98 chg: -$4.15 %chg: -21.7% day's high/low: $15.76/$13.77 the specialty pharmaceutical company reported third-quarter loss and reduced its earnings forecast for 2016
Title: Story stocks

Text: '  do i sound like him? kind of. but i think what you get is an essence of him being very feral." -- alec baldwin, discussing impersonating donald trump on 'snl' in a tuesday interview with wnyc's 'the brian lehrer show' how was your day? good day 'big bang theory' fans 'the hollywood reporter' and 'deadline' say the producers of cbs' hit sitcom are developing a prequel about the boyhood of jim parsons' character, persnickety physicist dr. sheldon cooper. caught in the act lady gaga channeled michael jackson -- right down to the aviator sunglasses -- at a hillary clinton rally tuesday in raleigh, n.c. "does anything in this picture look familiar?" remarked the late singer's sister, la toya jackson, on twitter
Title: THEY SAID WHAT? THE STARS' BEST QUOTES

Text: yes, even independence day: resurgence. the latest from director denis villeneuve (sicario) is a sci-fi movie (**** out of four; rated pg-13; in theaters nationwide friday) about life, death and learning a literally alien language on a deadline. amy adams turns in one of her best performances, jeremy renner shows he's just as good a math geek as an avenger, and villeneuve puts a gorgeous and rich narrative on screen that's as much about miscommunication among humans as it is communication with extraterrestrials. louise banks (adams) is a linguistics professor stuck in a deep melancholy after the loss of her  daughter. she's yanked out of that malaise when 12 huge alien pods shaped like half-eggs descend throughout the world. the government wants to figure out why they're here, and louise and physicist ian donnelly (renner) are recruited by colonel weber (forest whitaker) to decipher the aliens' inky, circular messages. against the wishes of the powers that be, louise takes ian up into the spacecraft that has landed in their neck of the woods for face time with the creatures -- louise puts her hand on one side of the see-through partition and a cosmic tourist in turn places its tentacled appendage on the other. yet while they're making strides, tensions arise globally as the invaded countries (including the usa) lose patience and begin to weigh first-strike options. eric heisserer's screenplay is a deep and at times heartbreaking gem, expanding the scope of ted chiang's novella  story of your life  but also creating something singularly special. even with a lot of technical mumbo-jumbo, the script maintains a needed universality in the way it handles such topics as love and destiny. a definite contender in the best-actress oscar race, adams is spectacular in giving louise the right emotional balance: she isn't fazed when aliens show up and the rest of the earth stands still. but a sense of wonder emerges as the linguist becomes obsessed with the alien language, even going rogue when she needs to make everyone else understand its importance. credit to villeneuve for crafting an engaging subplot with give and take between mankind and the visitors -- and for giving renner a chance to showcase his own substantial acting chops outside of the action-movie realm. being nerdy suits him just as well as being heroic. where gravity and the martian proved there was still such a thing as thinking man's sci-fi, arrival perfects it with an out-of-this-world visual palette, jí_hann jí_hannsson's  atmospheric score, and themes to chew on far past the end credits. it's best not to discuss the terrific third-act denouement apart from deeming it mind-blowing -- the ending makes you question, in a good way, everything that came before
Title: 'Arrival' is out-of-this-world amazing; Brainy sci-fi drama communicates in a whole new way

Text: a donald trump defeat in tuesday's nail-biter contest would mark a demoralizing, third consecutive loss of the white house for the party, whose leaders have struggled to contend with the populist wave that helped propel him to the republican presidential nomination. a trump win could still portend turbulence ahead for the gop and its warring factions. a combative trump already has rejected the republican establishment and feuded publicly with house speaker paul ryan, r-wis., who has worked to steer clear of the nominee during the final stretch to the election. and in a stunning rebuke to trump, an aide to former president george w. bush told reporters tuesday that the last republican to hold the white house declined to vote either for trump or his democratic rival. "the state of the party is chaotic," said reed galen, a republican strategist who was john mccain's deputy campaign manager in the 2008 election. "it is a place where all of the norms from a policy and political and ideological perspective have been washed away." some of the party's powerbrokers had already begun talk of re-examining the party's primary system to prevent another figure as polarizing and unconventional as trump from dominating the process in future contests. some of the republicans most active in opposing trump's candidacy said party leaders must forcefully repudiate trump if he loses and the hard-line anti-immigration stances he espoused if the gop hopes to recover support among suburban women and seize on the demographic shifts shaping elections. latinos, for instance, are expected to make up about 19% of the population when voters next pick a president in four years. that's up from roughly 14% in 2004 when bush, won re-election. "let's face it: if we continue to be the party that says 'no' to any kind of meaningful immigration reform, we will not win national elections," said republican strategist katie packer, who led an anti-trump super pac. however, republicans aligned with party's anti-establishment forces say gop leaders can't ignore the economic strain felt by white working-class voters drawn to trump and his message that free-trade policies have hurt american workers. "there are very real emotions that fueled donald trump's rise," said michael needham, the head of the conservative heritage action for america, which has strong ties to tea party activists and a history of confrontation with congressional leaders
Title: Leaders in GOP set for clashes; Win or lose, changes sure to come to party after brutal election

Text: mike pence crisscrossed the country for donald trump over the past three months, he  told voters he didn't hesitate for a second when asked to be trump's running mate. "i joined this campaign in a heartbeat," he says. win or lose tuesday, pence has mostly maintained that optimism throughout, despite a lot of campaign turbulence. and even if the gop ticket fails, pence appears to have preserved his high standing in the republican party for any future campaigns. "he is the republicans' happy warrior," sen. dan coats, r-ind., said as the campaign entered its final hours. "marcia (his wife) and i have had conversations with both mike and karen, and they truly are seeing this in a positive light and frankly enjoying what they're doing. and it shows." that's despite the  bumpy ride from the start. after accepting the job, pence was on his way to new york for the rollout when trump postponed the announcement, prompting reports that he was having second thoughts. when it was rescheduled, trump emphasized pence had been his first choice all along. but trump spoke mostly about himself before introducing pence -- and then he left the stage. pence was again overshadowed at the republican national convention. texas sen. ted cruz's refusal to endorse trump on stage shortly before pence's appearance was the story of the night, even though pence's at times folksy and self-deprecating speech was well-received inside the hall and by pundits. just a few weeks into the campaign, one of pence's main tasks was apparent even to an 11-year-old boy. at a town hall event in north carolina in early august, a young man named matthew told pence he'd been watching the news and "noticing that you've been kind of softening up on mr. trump's policies and words." "is this going to be your role in the administration?" he asked. pence had stepped in when trump didn't endorse the re-election bids of house speaker paul ryan and arizona sen. john mccain. he had tried to defuse trump's verbal battle with the muslim parents of an american soldier killed in iraq. and after trump encouraged the russians to expose emails from hillary clinton's private server, pence warned of "serious consequences" if russia interfered in the election. while some will call pence a good soldier, others will criticize him for having defended "some of the indefensible things about trump," said norm ornstein, an expert at the conservative american enterprise institute. "the big plus he's going to have is no one is going to blame him if they lose," ornstein said
Title: Pence stands as a 'happy warrior'; The No. 2 man's place in the party appears strong

Text: in one of more surprising races of the night, vermont voters chose a republican governor, lt. gov. phil scott, despite being an overwhelmingly democratic and liberal state. scott is popular in the state and viewed as socially liberal and fiscally conservative. missouri voters ushered in a new republican governor, eric greitens, awarding republicans control of both the legislative and executive branches in the state. he replaces outgoing democratic gov. jay nixon. greitens is a former navy seal with no prior political experience. in other races: indiana lt. gov. eric holcomb, a republican, won the governor's seat vacated by vice presidential candidate mike pence over democratic rival john gregg, the state house speaker. west virginians elected a democrat for their governor, millionaire coal executive jim justice, even though they overwhelmingly sided with donald trump for president. former software entrepreneur doug burgum kept north dakota's governor's seat with republicans. u.s. rep. john carney, a democrat, won delaware's governor's seat. in utah, republican gov. gary herbert beat out democratic rival mike weinholtz to win re-election, making him one of the longest-standing governors in the u.s, holding his post over 11 years. democratic gov. kate brown held off republican challenger bud pierce to retain oregon's governor's office. and incumbent jay inslee, a democrat, beat republican challenger bill bryant to win a second term as washington governor. entering tuesday, democrats were defending eight gubernatorial seats, while the republicans were trying to hang on to four. at least six of those races were seen as competitive or tossups. as in other down-ballot races, the presidential contest -- and trump's candidacy in particular -- could affect several of those matchups. trump's widespread support among hard-line gop voters appeared to help republicans in vermont, indiana, north dakota, utah and missouri. why are governor's races important? for starters, governors will be the ones signing off on -- or rejecting -- any new redrawing of legislative districts, said larry sabato, director of the university of virginia's center for politics. also, despite the drama of the presidential elections, voters tend to care more about who's leading their state government than who's occupying the white house, he said. "washington is often only relevant in war and peace," sabato said. "at the state level, your everyday life is affected." in one of the night's tightest races, north carolina incumbent pat mccrory was neck-and-neck with democratic attorney general roy cooper
Title: 12 heads of states: 5-4 for GOP; Gubernatorial races haven't had much buzz -- yet resonate widely

Text: "we're feeling buoyant," campaign manager kellyanne conway told fox news late tuesday. trump out-performed late polls, winning essential states like florida and north carolina. he also won ohio -- which had been expected -- and was running surprisingly strong in democratic-leaning  pennsylvania and michigan. "let me tell you, if i don't win i will consider it a tremendous waste of time, energy and money," trump told fox & friends early tuesday, one of the two interviews he gave the  news outlet. the concession question asked if he would concede the election should he wind up losing, trump was noncommittal. "we're going to see how things play out today and hopefully they will play out well and hopefully we won't have to worry about it," trump told fox news in a later interview. "we're going to see how they play out and i want to see everything honest." trump also said he felt "good" about the election and that "i think we are going to do very well." but he made several suggestions through the day that the results would not be honest. as networks began calling states for both candidates, trump supporters streamed into a ballroom at the new york hilton in midtown for what they hoped would be a victory celebration. fans wearing red "make america great again" hats milled about a cash bar, some gawking at a giant "victory cake" in the shape of trump's head. supporters at the trump event cheered loudly when fox news anchor chris wallace said it is possible that trump could win. as trump continued to win critical states, his fans cheered. republican consultant hogan gidley attributed the surprise results to "anger," particularly among struggling industrial workers in the rust belt. "americans have been getting kicked in the gut," he said. gidley also said voters want change, and "hillary clinton was the embodiment of the establishment and the embodiment of the status quo." the new york businessman cast his vote tuesday morning at a school in manhattan, joking with reporters: "tough decision." voters at trump's polling place cheered his presence; others booed and yelled "phony" at the republican candidate. "i'm very excited," he told reporters. "it's a great opportunity. there's tremendous enthusiasm you see it all over the country, all over the world. it's a great feeling." lot of polls 'are phony' while pre-election surveys gave an edge to clinton, trump told fox news "i think a lot of the polls are phony," and predicted victory. he also said his campaign is checking out reports of alleged problems at the polls, telling fox that "it's happening at various places today, it has been reported." throughout the final weeks of the campaign, trump warned about the prospect of a "rigged" election based on alleged voter fraud and biased news coverage. the republican nominee has consistently declined to say whether he would honor the results of the election if he loses. eric trump, the candidate's son, told msnbc that his father would respect the results, win or lose -- if he deems it a legitimate election. "if he loses and it's legit and fair, and there's not obvious stuff out there then without question, yes," the younger trump said. in one radio interview, trump told talk show host howe carr that it was "sad" that  george w. bush opted not to vote for him, as a spokesman confirmed tuesday. "i don't think it has any impact, frankly," trump said. trump, remained out sight most of tuesday, making calls, conducting interviews and using social media. throughout the day, he tweeted admonishments to voters to get to the polls. said one missive: "don't let up, keep getting out to vote -- this election is far from over!" election day capped an insurgent trump campaign that, in many ways, represented a near-hostile takeover of the republican party. supporters called trump a refreshing non-politician and described his language as an assault on "political correctness." critics called it racist and sexist. in one of his fox news interviews, trump said he ran the best campaign he could. "there's always regrets," trump said, but you can't go back and change things. "sure there are things that i would have done differently
Title: Trump blasts past poll predictions; After day starts with 'a great feeling,' strong showing pushes late into night

Text: the early results surprised pollsters and rattled investors. dow futures plunged about 800 points, or 4.4%, as the markets worried about the uncertainty of a trump administration. a trump win would upend american politics with promises to roll back large parts of president obama's legacy. the billionaire real estate mogul has promised to build a wall on the mexican border, stop muslim refugees from entering the country and -- in a departure from longstanding american tradition -- send his election opponent to jail. from the beginning, trump's narrow road to victory wound through must-win swing states like florida, ohio and north carolina. trump won all of them, and then added georgia even as he maintained slight leads in blue states like michigan and wisconsin, putting him just one or two red states from the 270 electoral votes needed to win. with no political experience to his name, trump defied expectations throughout his unconventional campaign, vanquishing a crowded field of 16 other republicans for the chance to face clinton, the former first lady and secretary of state. the result was one of the most bitter campaigns in modern history, bringing phrases like "basket of deplorables" and "nasty woman" into daily conversation. despite the unpopularity of both candidates, turnout was up. in the 1,143 counties with 100% precincts reporting as of 10:45p.m.et, 5.6% more voters cast votes than in 2012. the race pitted two candidates with singular qualities: clinton, who would become the first female president after 228 years of men, against trump, whose vast wealth, lack of government experience and blunt rhetoric would redefine the word "presidential." his insult-laden speeches and tweets -- which his supporters defended as a refreshing break from political correctness -- were recounted in attack ads that flooded battleground states. even before the vote-casting turned to vote-counting, a sense of history hung over the day. many women wore pantsuits to the polls, an homage to clinton's conservative sartorial style. hundreds of women made a pilgrimage to a rochester, n.y., cemetery, affixing their "i voted" stickers to the headstone of susan b. anthony, the suffragist leader whose work paved the way for women'sright to vote. nearly a century later, gender issues were never far from the forefront of clinton's barrier-breaking campaign -- or from trump's. nearly two-thirds of voters who spoke to exit pollsters said they were bothered by clinton's use of a private email server.  even more said they were bothered by trump's treatment of women -- with more than half saying that his conduct bothered them "a lot." more than one-tenth of voters said they made up their minds on how to vote in the last few days of the campaign, as the fbi revealed its on-again, off-again investigations into clinton's emails. justin byerly of asheville, n.c., said his decision was difficult. "until 11 days ago, i was for hillary," he said. "then the emails happened." exit polls revealed an electorate more educated, more diverse -- and also angrier -- than recent presidential elections. clinton was counting on a big turnout from hispanic and african-american voters, while trump's support was fueled by a frustration about the direction of the country after eight years of obama. clinton and trump both cast their own ballots in solid-blue new york state tuesday morning. clinton and husband bill arrived to cheers at her polling place in chappaqua, n.y. trump's reception at his manhattan polling place was more mixed. he finished voting and then appeared to peek over at wife melania's ballot. asked who he voted for, he joked, "tough decision." contributing: heidi m
Title: Trump scores crucial victories in Florida, Ohio

Text: but elation led to panic by evening, as gop presidential nominee donald trump took key swing states from democratic nominee hillary clinton, including north carolina and ohio. it was a far cry from when polls opened, when the possibility of ending the night with two words -- madam president -- proved electric, and emotions ran the gamut from euphoria to tears. as clinton supporters hit the polls, some women (and men) voters wore white, a nod to the suffrage movement that afforded women the right to vote in 1920. in rochester, n.y., thousands of people, a large majority of them women and girls, queued up to visit the grave of women's rights crusader susan b. anthony, who famously cast a ballot in 1872 knowing it was illegal, and was subsequently arrested. born before she had the right to cast a ballot, "i'd like to vote twice but that's not possible," said 100-year old florence thaler, a resident of pequannock township, n.j. at poll stations, women arrived with their mothers, daughters and sisters. many wore pantsuits as a nod to clinton's signature look. "just high fived a #pantsuit wearing wearing stranger. this is a weird day," tweeted lucy arnold, whose bio identifies her as a teacher and writer. in columbia, s.c., consultant elizabeth wilson set a soundtrack to her day, playing beyoncí©'s run the world (girls) and fleetwood mac's don't stop on her instagram story-documented morning walk to her polling station.  "the country has been ready, for a few decades, for a woman president," she said. but by tuesday night, twitter became a current of worry due to the razor-thin voting margins. "i'm so anxious and stressed. my stomach is in knots," wrote user @michellef0918. "this election and trump's language has brought up so many traumas for women and this is half the nation telling us, "oh well," tweeted  @alysemigran. in iowa, ruline steininger, 103, began her night watching cnn's early return, offering a stern "good!" after each state was  called for clinton. steininger cast her first vote for franklin d. roosevelt in 1940. starting with her annual christmas letter last year, she willed herself to live, writing to her friends and family she "decided to stay alive to vote for hillary." "i thought it was great that a black man got elected for president," she said tuesday. "i didn't think that would happen in my lifetime, but it did. now, it is high time for a woman, and this time we have a woman who is really capable of being president of the united states." but when the network reported that trump was leading  in florida, she set  her tea down with emphasis. "don't tell me that," she all but yelled at the tv. earlier, at dawn in rochester, the mood had been jubilant and reflective. supporters continued the tradition of decorating suffragette susan b. anthony's headstone at mount hope cemetery with their "i voted" stickers. "i never cried when i filled out my ballot before. but i realized my daughters -- and i have three of them -- have the right to vote for a woman. it made me cry," said jodi atkin of irondequoit, n.y., who trekked to the grave site with daughter jessie. both were clad in white. in greenville, s.c.,  inez tenenbaum maintained america was long overdue to have a woman at the helm. "other women, such as margaret thatcher, angela merkel, indira gandhi, golda meir have led countries for decades," said tenenbaum, an attorney who was nominated by president barack obama in 2009 to chair the united states consumer product safety commission. it's taken 96 years since the 19th amendment was ratified for a woman's name to appear as a major party candidate on an general election ballot. "the march for women's equality has been a long and slow one, but ever since 1920 when women got the right to vote there always has been a back-burner hope that we'd have a first female president. and hillary clinton has worked assiduously to be that person," says douglas brinkley, a history professor at rice university. jerry emmett, a 102-year-old from prescott, ariz., whose political idol is hillary clinton, retired to her bed before the race for the presidency was decided. for emmett, who helped report arizona's delegates for hillary clinton at the democratic national convention, the night wasn't all she had hoped it would be. "she's a little bit antsy about what's going to happen," her son jim emmett, 69, said
Title: For millions of women, this Election Day turned cold; Joy of voting for Clinton couldn't outweigh tight nerves

Text: with trump leading the  popular vote after the polls in many states had closed, trump nation waited to see if their candidate could overcome hillary clinton's edge in pre-election polls. "i'm an emotional wreck," rachel quade, 50, who had been up poll-watching since 5 a.m., texted from a trump-pence party in downtown indianapolis. "i'm going to cry either way!" at home in vermillion s.d., lora hubbel, 58, was another bundle of nerves. "i'm trying to stay busy and only look at the results once in a while," she said. she busied herself online, pursuing real estate continuing-education credits. hubbel, one of many white christian evangelicals who voted for the very non-evangelical trump, said she had faith he'd win. with him in the white house, "everyone's going to get a little more testosterone!" she said. "this means more freedom, more initiative." both women were among scores of trump voters around the nation interviewed this summer by the usa network. others were more confident, based on trump's solid showing tuesday in battleground states. nam yong horn, 62, said she wasn't even considering the possibility of a trump loss: "oh my god, america is going to be saved!" the 62-year-old korean immigrant, who lives in southern california, spent last weekend working for trump in las vegas. "we'll have a real human being in the white house who understands the people," she predicted. eugene dunn, a long island limo driver who took his son out of school to attend trump's announcement 17 months ago at trump tower, said he had "the champagne on ice" as he awaited the verdict. "no one i know says they're voting for hillary clinton," he said. "and you look at the yard signs, it was 20-to-1." losing was unthinkable -- except, he said, that if trump lost he'd have to consider "an exit strategy" such as "moving to the islands, maybe tending bar at a tiki bar." at the other end of the hope spectrum was barry fixler, a small-town jeweler who opened his own local trump headquarters last year when the campaign didn't do so fast enough. "donald trump said this election is rigged, and i fully agree with him," said fixler, whose shop is in bardonia, n.y., north of new york city. "i cannot see president obama turning over the government. i'm not being pessimistic, i'm being realistic." as the votes were counted, the trump optimists and the trump pessimists shared one thing: relief that the campaign was over. jeff lau, 58, who owns a brew pub in york, pa., called it "the ugliest i've ever seen." he was hardly sanguine about what came next, regardless of whether his man won or lost, or whether the gop maintained control of the house and senate. "donald is a little vindictive, and instead of negotiating he'll probably try to dictate to republicans in congress, who didn't really support him," lau said. "they'll push back, and then we'll have gridlock." trump supporters were torn between pondering the benefits of his election and the costs of his defeat. erwin jackson, a tallahassee, fla., landlord and real estate manager, said a clinton presidency would mean higher taxes and more regulation and could drive him into retirement: "why work harder? it's just more stress. i'm 66. all four of my brothers have retired. my sons say, 'dad, you've worked all these years.'" besides such personal concerns, many in trump nation feared for what a defeat would mean for the political process. the aforementioned quade, a 50-year-old real estate agent who lives in suburban indianapolis, said a trump loss would "mean we're going to a one-party system. if we can't win against such a weak candidate, we have no chance of ever winning again." trump himself had encouraged such an attitude the previous day, when he said there was no substitute for victory and no consolation in defeat. if he didn't win, he said at a rally in north carolina, "we've all wasted our time." he also told a crowd in sarasota, fla.: "they say we'll get a tremendous amount of credit, win or lose. i said, 'no, no, no, no.' i don't want any credit if we lose." he sounded an apocalyptic note. "we will never have another opportunity." many of his followers agreed. "this is not the country i grew up in," said pat acciavatti, 77, of st. clair township, mich., a retired excavating company owner. he spoke of the 1940s and '50s, when america made half the world's steel in the wake of world war ii. now, he said, "we're going in the wrong direction. donald trump has a chance to change that. he's the only hope the country has
Title: In Trump Nation, hope and anxiety; Anger is replaced by emotion: 'I'm going to cry either way'

Text: a donald trump win would mean nothing less than a repudiation of the obama presidency. "elections have consequences," as president obama himself said after his 2008 win. and for obama, it's hard to imagine a more consequential choice. with his former secretary of state in the white house, obama would be able to count  on a successor who will pursue some of his most transformative and controversial policies: immigration reform, the expansion of health care and environmental regulation. trump has pledged to repeal every one of them. "president hillary clinton will be the closest thing to an obama third term," said paul kegnor, a professor at grove city college in pennsylvania. her election solidifies an obama legacy that will be most clearly  felt on social issues, he said. "the change in the courts is crucial to this. she will solidify the changes at the judicial level for a generation or two." and as the beginning of one era marks the end of another, the reagan era -- characterized by limited government, social conservatism and anti-communism -- may be fading in the rearview mirror. "there's never been an opposition party in the history of the united states that's ever won three elections in a row without starting a new era," said curt nichols, a political science professor at baylor university who has studied how presidential elections affect the reordering of american politics. as great as they were, the jefferson, jackson, lincoln, roosevelt and reagan eras didn't get solidified until their successors -- often handpicked vice presidents -- won election. alternatively, trump's election would represent a "hostile takeover" of the white house, upending the political order with a new brand of politics that doesn't neatly fit into the existing bipartisan framework. judging from his whirlwind campaigning of the past few weeks, no one has been more acutely aware of this history than obama himself. he recited a litany of accomplishments -- from the auto industry rescue to the affordable care act to the paris climate accords. "all the progress we've made goes out the window if we don't win this election," he said in stump speeches in ohio, pennsylvania, north carolina and florida. clinton's election after eight years of obama would make her a democratic president in a democratic era. that puts her in a different position than her husband, former president bill clinton, who knew he was a moderate democratic president in a republican era. "i hope you're all aware we're all eisenhower republicans," he was reported to have said in bob woodward's the agenda: inside the clinton white house. "we're all eisenhower republicans here, and we are fighting the reagan republicans." but unlike bill clinton and barack obama, who had democratic congresses for their first two years, clinton would still have to grapple with the gop resistance that characterized most of obama's tenure
Title: An 'Obama era' hinges on a Clinton victory; But if Trump wins, legacy suffers from a 'hostile takeover'

Text: by the end of the day, however, the mood surrounding her campaign had changed markedly. "i'll do the very best i can if i'm fortunate enough to win today," clinton told reporters after voting in chappaqua, n.y. later that night, at the jacob k. javits convention center in new york, where clinton was scheduled to address supporters at an election night party, supporters were incredulous at the unexpected closeness of her race against donald trump. joseph di thomas, a real estate broker from manhattan, said he was feeling "really disappointed." "i'm feeling let down by all the powers that be that this election was in the bag, and it isn't," he said, noting that modeling was "way off." "i was expecting quite a landslide, especially by this hour," he said. "i thought we'd have it in the bag." in the final hours of clinton's historic bid to become the first female u.s. president, the democratic nominee began the equivalent of a national therapy program to heal the nation, which may be needed after the nastiest and most divisive campaign in modern history, particularly after late tuesday returns showed a much-closer-than-expected race. in last-minute stops across pennsylvania and michigan on monday, states her republican challenger donald trump hoped would pave his path to victory, clinton underscored the need for americans to put aside anger -- and even hate -- that's defined an election dividing americans along racial, class and gender lines. early tuesday evening, clinton's motorcade arrived at the peninsula hotel in new york, where she, along with her family, including husband bill clinton, watched early returns, which would soon show a tight race. among the family members in attendance was the clintons' 2-year-old granddaughter, charlotte, who wore a dress sporting clinton's logo, according to the campaign. later, clinton was scheduled to head to the javits  center, a steel and glass structure the campaign chose for its symbolism in anticipation that the democratic nominee becomes the first woman to "shatter the highest, hardest glass ceiling," as she and her campaign surrogates often say. as election returns rolled in, a group of speakers entertained the crowd, including new york city mayor bill de blasio and the so-called mothers of the movement, a group of african-american women who've lost their children to gun violence. the campaign chose to give the most prominent slot, coming just before the main program, to khizr khan, the gold star father of a muslim solider killed in iraq in 2004. with early returns showing a tight race, the campaign continued to express confidence, saying they still expected to carry the necessary battlegrounds needed to win. even so, the mood in the javits center was subdued. singer katy perry, who performed at a recent clinton rally, took to the stage for brief remarks. "if you're in a state where the polls are still open, you must vote for hillary clinton tonight," she said. others also tried to keep spirits high, including sen. charles schumer, d-n.y., who likened clinton to other female pioneers and predicted she would "break through that final barrier." in the campaign's closing days, clinton sought to strike a more unifying note. "this election will end, but our work together will be just beginning," clinton told a gymnasium of about 6,000 at north carolina state university in raleigh early tuesday morning. in an interview with a new hampshire radio station, clinton was asked how she'd hope to be remembered if elected
Title: Clinton fans shocked by tight race; Supporters who expected landslide 'feeling let down'

Text: as of tuesday night, though, bill clinton still needed one important thing to happen before crafting a new white house portfolio: a hillary clinton win. returns suggested a closer-than-expected race and even the possibility of the end of the clinton political dynasty. if hillary clinton does become the nation's first female president, her husband would make history as the first man to be the supportive spouse to america's commander in chief. more consequential than that first would be another, historians and analysts say: that said spouse is a former president himself. how the nation's 42nd president would employ experience in a hillary clinton white house remains unclear, but those who've studied the clintons and first ladies agree that he would transform the role. "nobody likes a social event better than bill clinton does," said russell riley, a university of virginia professor and historian who authored inside the clinton white house: an oral history. "but i don't think that's going to be the end of it." during the campaign, hillary clinton spoke sparsely about what her husband's role in her administration would be if she got elected. she said she would use him as "a goodwill emissary" tasked with "revitalizing the economy." he couldn't take on any post requiring senate approval (an anti-nepotism law prevents that), but he could take a cue from his wife, who redefined the role of presidential spouse in the 1990s by taking on a weighty policy portfolio. as the head of her husband's task force on health care, hillary clinton broadened the role of first lady. her work  proved unsuccessful, and a first lady stepping outside of the traditional duties struck a bad chord with some americans, said patrick j. maney, a history professor at boston college. "it does seem, strangely, that her position as first lady was more problematic than his position would be as first spouse because there was a lot of opposition to her role in hillarycare," said maney, who authored bill clinton: new gilded age president. a former twice-elected president such as bill clinton could take on a substantive portfolio and raise far fewer eyebrows, maney said. although the role of first spouse comes with no official job description, the clintons would have to find the right balance between both of their historic roles. it's hillary clinton who would be president, not bill, riley said, and his keeping a distance could prove a "difficult balancing act." that wouldn't stop bill clinton from playing a major role in a hillary clinton administration
Title: First spouse's role could evolve; Analysts speculate on how Bill Clinton might be involved

Text: his campaign has left a blemish on american history as ugly as any since the civil war. yet even the smoke from a dumpster fire can have a silver lining. everything positive, from this conservative's perspective, falls into a single category: we have learned a great deal about the country in which we dwell. first, and most obviously, up until trump came along, the anger and alienation of the white working class had been hidden from the view of comfortable coastal elites (the ones who, yes, include me). even if the solutions trump dangled before this demographic -- high tariffs, high walls, seizing iraq's oil and bombing terror-ridden zones into submission -- are precisely the wrong way to go, politicians of both parties will in the future ignore these voters at their peril. immigration woes given that this cohort brought us trump, they might conceivably lock us into permanent division. that need not be the case. a significant majority of americans, polls show, do not want the draconian trumpian approach of deportation of millions and all the special police forces and deportation camps that would entail. politicians may finally be forced to arrive at a sane solution to our immigration woes. trumpism should also compel our leaders to do what they have for too long neglected: articulate the case for policies that for seven decades have served the country well, such as free trade as a path to prosperity and alliances as the path to security, and explain why trump's brute-force approach to counterterrorism would not only fail but also backfire. but we have also learned that we cannot count on the republican party to play a useful role in that process, or in sensible reform in any policy arena. only a handful of gop leaders followed mitt romney's call to reject as a "con man" and a "fake" the purveyor of trump steaks and casino-bankrupting founder of trump university. the party leadership -- paul ryan, mitch mcconnell and reince priebus -- stuck with their man through every bigoted, racially charged, misogynistic step down into the gutter. republican officials up and down the power structure put party before country and followed the example of sen. marco rubio, who endorsed a man he had labeled unfit to serve as commander in chief. trump deserves gratitude for exposing the gop as a collection of power-seeking cowards, a termite-ridden structure that tumbled at his touch. test of faith trump has also put america's faith communities to the test. the results are revealing. for once, the reflexive liberalism of american jews served them well; trump attracted only a handful of prominent jewish supporters. america's muslims, facing a ban on entry, had no choice at all. mormons, confirming their status as america's model minority, said a polite no thank you to trump's bigotry. the country's catholic leadership, both clerical and intellectual -- with resistance to nativism in their genes -- stood on conviction and rejected the gop nominee for his "vulgarity," "oafishness," "shocking ignorance," "demagoguery" and as "manifestly unfit to be president of the united states" -- words from a statement signed by many of america's most prominent conservative catholic thinkers. paeans of praise unfortunately, the leaders of evangelical christianity did not fare quite so well. the rev. russell moore of the southern baptist convention, who last month memorably observed, "the religious right turns out to be the people the religious right warned us about," was the brilliant exception to the rule. more typical was pat robertson. "you inspire us all" was the opening lyric of his paean of praise to trump, with rev. jerry falwell jr., ralph reed and dozens of other corrupted churchmen chiming in to hail a champion of immorality as america's savior. at the grassroots, as william galston has noted, recent years and quite possibly the appeal of trump himself have encouraged a momentous shift in opinion among white evangelicals, many of whom no longer appear to believe that personal morality needs be "consistent with an ethical performance of official duties." the moral majority, which two decades ago pilloried president bill clinton for illicit conduct behind closed doors, now seems quite willing to elevate trump's braggadocious brand of depravity to the white house. that depravity includes trump's boast of grabbing women by their genitals and forcibly planting his repulsive lips on theirs. together with serial sexual predator roger ailes as trump campaign adviser and alleged wife-beater alt-right steve bannon as trump campaign ceo, america has gotten quite an education in how a certain kind of man behaves. with his campaign of hatred and division, trump has made many of america's problems worse, but he has also been an eye-opener. he deserves one hearty cheer for that
Title: A dumpster fire's silver lining; Trump has exposed GOP cowardice, right-wing hypocrisy and working-class anger

Text: problems cropped up in arizona, florida, north carolina, ohio, pennsylvania, virginia and other battleground states that would decide whether hillary clinton or donald trump won the presidency. most involved election administration issues that have plagued the polls for decades, rather than incidents of voter fraud or intimidation. a coalition of more than 100 civil rights and voting rights groups running a national election protection hotline reported that 40% of its calls came from african-american and hispanic communities. the majority of complaints came from california, new york, texas, florida, pennsylvania and north carolina. florida saw particularly high levels of voter misinformation. "there is tremendous disruption at the polls today," said wade henderson, president of the leadership conference on civil and human rights.
